title.value: Measuring Commonality in Recommendation of Cultural Content: Recommender Systems to Enhance Cultural Citizenship
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning of the research paper and is repeated in the ACM Reference Format section.
title.quote: Measuring Commonality in Recommendation of Cultural Content: Recommender Systems to Enhance Cultural Citizenship

extractions.description: The paper introduces 'commonality' as a new metric for evaluating recommender systems that aim to enhance cultural citizenship, focusing on shared cultural experiences rather than just personalized recommendations. The study uses movie recommendations as a case study to show how commonality complements existing utility, diversity, novelty, and fairness metrics.

type.justification: The paper includes an empirical comparison of recommendation algorithms using the proposed commonality metric alongside existing metrics.
type.quote: Taking diversity in movie recommendation as a case study in enhancing pluralistic cultural experience, we empirically compare the performance of recommendation algorithms using commonality and existing utility, diversity, novelty, and fairness metrics.

name.justification: The research focuses on recommender systems and introduces a new metric to evaluate them, particularly in the context of cultural content.
name.quote: Recommender systems have become the dominant means of curating cultural content, significantly influencing the nature of individual cultural experience.

name.justification: The paper specifically discusses the recommendation of cultural content, emphasizing the role of recommender systems in shaping cultural citizenship.
name.quote: We identify universality of address and content diversity in the service of strengthening cultural citizenship as particularly relevant goals for recommender systems delivering cultural content.

name.justification: Movies are used as a case study for applying the commonality metric and enhancing cultural citizenship.
name.quote: Taking diversity in movie recommendation as a case study in enhancing pluralistic cultural experience.

name.justification: The BPRMF model is mentioned in the results section as part of their empirical study on recommendation algorithms.
name.quote: The run with the highest NDCG, Bayesian personalized ranking matrix factorization (BPRMF), also exhibited a very low average commonality across categories, relative to other runs.

is_contributed.justification: The paper uses existing models to evaluate its proposed metric rather than contributing new models.
is_contributed.quote: The run with the highest NDCG, Bayesian personalized ranking matrix factorization (BPRMF), also exhibited a very low average commonality across categories, relative to other runs.

is_executed.justification: The model is used in experiments to measure NDCG and commonality values.
is_executed.quote: The run with the highest NDCG, Bayesian personalized ranking matrix factorization (BPRMF), also exhibited a very low average commonality across categories.

is_compared.justification: BPRMF is compared with other models in terms of NDCG and commonality measures.
is_compared.quote: The run with the highest NDCG, Bayesian personalized ranking matrix factorization (BPRMF), also exhibited a very low average commonality across categories, relative to other runs.

referenced_paper_title.value: Towards a Fair Marketplace: Counterfactual Evaluation of the trade-off between Relevance, Fairness and Satisfaction in Recommendation Systems
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper is likely to be the reference for the BPRMF model as it discusses similar themes of fairness and satisfaction in recommendation systems.

name.justification: SVD is mentioned as part of the empirical study in evaluating recommendation algorithms.
name.quote: The run with the highest average commonality, SVD, on the other hand, generated lower-utility rankings.

is_contributed.justification: The research utilizes existing models to make comparative analyses rather than introducing new ones.
is_contributed.quote: The run with the highest average commonality, SVD, on the other hand, generated lower-utility rankings.

is_executed.justification: SVD is executed in experiments to measure commonality and utility.
is_executed.quote: The run with the highest average commonality, SVD, on the other hand, generated lower-utility rankings.

is_compared.justification: SVD is compared with other models in terms of commonality and utility metrics.
is_compared.quote: The run with the highest average commonality, SVD, on the other hand, generated lower-utility rankings.

referenced_paper_title.value: An Introduction to Matrix Factorization Techniques for Recommender Systems
referenced_paper_title.justification: SVD is a well-known method discussed in literature about matrix factorization techniques.

name.justification: Random recommendation is used as a baseline to compare against other algorithmic approaches.
name.quote: We contrast this with the run with the lowest NDCG, random, that exhibited comparatively much higher average commonality across categories.

is_contributed.justification: Random recommendation is a classic baseline approach and not a novel contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We contrast this with the run with the lowest NDCG, random, that exhibited comparatively much higher average commonality across categories.

is_executed.justification: It was executed as part of the model comparisons to assess commonality.
is_executed.quote: We contrast this with the run with the lowest NDCG, random, that exhibited comparatively much higher average commonality across categories.

is_compared.justification: Random recommendation is used for comparison in metrics such as commonality and NDCG.
is_compared.quote: We contrast this with the run with the lowest NDCG, random, that exhibited comparatively much higher average commonality across categories.

referenced_paper_title.value: A Comprehensive Survey of Approaches and Challenges in Recommender Systems
referenced_paper_title.justification: Random recommendation is commonly discussed as a baseline in literature about recommender systems.

name.justification: The dataset is explicitly mentioned and used for experiments in the paper.
name.quote: Data: We use the movielens-1m dataset, which contains 1,000,209 ratings of 3,900 movies from 6,040 users from the movielens platform.

referenced_paper_title.value: Movielens data sets: History and context
referenced_paper_title.justification: The movielens-1m dataset is a well-known dataset, often used in recommendation system research.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Data: We use the movielens-1m dataset, which contains 1,000,209 ratings of 3,900 movies from 6,040 users from the movielens platform.
